Award.AwardTitle: Elm STEMS: An Integrated Approach to Cultivating Academic Success in Science, Technology and Math

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the Elm STEMs project, the College of Our Lady of the Elms (Elms College) is expanding enrollment in its biology, chemistry, mathematics or computer information technology programs through new career-building, experiential opportunities in STEM. The goal of this S-STEM project is to support qualified students with financial need, provide them with the tools for success, and connect them with the regional technology industry in New England. The project is awarding scholarships to a total of 21 S-STEM scholar students (10 first-year and 11 transfer students).

The objectives of this project are to: 1) increase enrollment of first-year and transfer students in STEM, 2) increase retention of these scholars and support them through graduation, 3) provide opportunities for experiential learning (research or internships), and 4) increase the number of scholars continuing to graduate studies or finding employment in their field. This project builds upon a strong existing student-support infrastructure as well as implements programs newly created for the Elm STEMS program to provide evidence-based support for the S-STEM scholars: a special section of the First Year Seminar taught by STEM faculty provides cohort building and peer mentoring for S-STEM scholars; a new Scientific and Technical Communications course for juniors and transfer students develops critical skills and bring transfer students into the cohort; and the STEM Career Series and the STEM on the Road field trip program provides opportunities for career exploration. To ensure academic success, Elms is implementing student supports that include scheduled tutoring and enhanced proactive faculty advisement. A cohort experience is promoted based on common participation in a first year seminar, a junior year workshop, and a STEM-based service learning project.

Elms College's recruitment strategy targets high-achieving students from local high schools and community colleges, many of which have large underrepresented minority and first-generation populations. To increase awareness in high school students and community college students of the wide range of STEM career opportunities in the region, Elms is implementing outreach and career education, including recruitment events that include theme-based engaging hands-on activities (such as forensics, lab-based biotechnology, and field-based environmental assessment) and networking opportunities with local industry. Additional partnerships with local high school teachers and community college faculty and counselors are being developed to support these outreach efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Elm STEMs project at the College of Our Lady of the Elms (Elms College) lowered barriers to degree completion through financial and academic supports, a strong cohort experience, and research and internship experiences. Awards for scholarships were given to academically talented, predominantly first generation students with financial need, majoring in STEM fields at Elms College beginning in 2015 and continuing with no-cost extensions until 2021. The S-STEM scholars served by this grant were academically successful and pursued careers or further education in their major. With a 93% retention rate to graduation, we funded both first-year students (10) and transfer students (18), exceeding the planned number in our proposal. Of the 28 scholars, 10 majored in biology or chemistry and 18 majored in either computer information technology (CIT) or computer science (CS); 39% were women and 61% identified as black or Hispanic. Of the science (chemistry and biology) majors, 43% of the female students majored in chemistry. The two students who were not retained left after one semester and did not participate in S-STEM programming. Most of our scholars held campus STEM jobs, including help-desk internships, tutoring, lab assistant, and research assistant jobs. In addition, 100% of the CIT/CS scholars had IT internships, and 100% of the biology and chemistry majors conducted research alongside a professor, and presented their original research at local and national conferences. All of our scholars participated in cohort experiences such as STEM on the Road field trips to visit research labs at local universities, to conduct ecological fieldwork, to explore museums and tour the high performance computing center in Holyoke, where we also have an ongoing "Holyoke codes" program. Our students also helped to do outreach and run activities at STEM days, including a BioBlitz event where hundreds of high school students and the community participated in identifying flora and fauna at a local urban park. Career development was an important component of the support built into the ElmSTEMs experience, which included resume guidance, local career fairs, and career seminars on campus including seminars by alumni representing different STEM fields such as wildlife biologists, research and laboratory supervisors. All of our STEM scholars are working or are in graduate school full time. The Biology and Chemistry scholars have all continued in a STEM field and most of the CITS/CS majors are employed in IT fields. In summary, the scholars all benefited from the program and the grant achieved its goals.

A number of pedagogical innovations have been supported by this grant, including (1) the design and implementation of a STEM First Year seminar course and a one-credit STEM Communications seminar, (2) a new Computer Science (CS) major that focuses on software development and programming and (3) a new biotechnology major at the college and (4) a new degree-completion program in CIT and CS which is an accelerated online program for transfer students in computer-related majors who can finish their bachelor degrees in 14 months. (5) A new experiential learning initiative where students are funded to do research or internships in their fields of study.
